title: Boris Johnson under pressure to save free TV licences in Queen's Speech
text:

Boris Johnson is under mounting pressure to save free TV licences for over 75s in Monday’s Queen’s Speech.

Labour urged ministers to keep their manifesto promise to pick up the bill for the benefit.

In a letter to Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan, Labour’s Tom Watson said the Government’s refusal to fund the benefit meant “millions of the oldest people in our society will have to choose between being worse off or being cut off from the wider world.”

The Shadow Culture Secretary urged Ministers to keep the Tory manifesto promise to maintain free TV licences for all people over 75, “to avoid inflicting hardship on millions of older people and right this wrong at last.”

It comes after a committee of MPs today urged the BBC to cut a deal with ministers to restore the benefit.

As things stand, it will be means tested from next year, leaving 3.7 million pensioners facing the loss of their free TV licence.

The Mirror is campaigning to save the entitlement, which the Beeb estimates would cost them £745 million a year to maintain.

But former culture minister Ed Vaizey said he thought means testing was "the right policy”.

"At the risk of the wrath of your listeners, I actually think the BBC actually has the right policy," Mr Vaizey told Radio 4’s Today Programme.

(Image: PA)

"I think a free TV licence for everyone over 75 is probably the wrong policy.

"But I do agree with the select committee that if it is the Government's view that there should be a free TV licence for over-75s, the Government should partner with the BBC and help to fund that cost."

In his letter, Mr Watson added: “For those who are housebound or live entirely on their own, television is a lifeline.

“4 in 10 older people say television is their main source of company.

“Taking that company away from vulnerable people at the time of a national loneliness epidemic is unthinkable.

“You cannot means test for social isolation.”
description: EXCLUSIVE Labour urged ministers to keep their promise to pick up the bill for the benefit in Monday's State Opening of Parliament
